Among haematological parameters, lymphopenia is clearly associated with disease severity; 88 patients who died from COVID-19 had significantly lower lymphocyte counts than survivors.

In fact, repletion of lymphocytes may be an important factor for recovery [3] . Other blood 90 cells, including white blood cells, neutrophils, eosinophils, platelets and CD8 cell counts were 91 partly only predictors in discriminating mild from severe COVID-19 (Table1); their 92 significance is still ambiguous. Granulocyte colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) was elevated 93 in ICU patients and significantly associated with the severity of disease (Table1).

Patients with severe COVID-19 appear to have signs of liver dysfunction more frequently 96 than those with milder disease. An increase in alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate 97 aminotransferase (AST) and total bilirubin levels has been observed among many ICU 98 patients [4] ( Table 1)

FIGREF1.text: the number of COVID-19 patients is increasing dramatically worldwide and treatment in 62 intensive care units (ICU) has become a major challenge, the early recognition of severe 63 forms of COVID-19 is absolutely essential for timely triaging of patients. SARS-CoV-2 64 infection, especially in older patients and those with pre-existing illness, progress to severe 65 disease with critical respiratory symptoms and significant pulmonary changes visible by 66 imaging techniques. The changes include ground glass opacities, patchy consolidation, 67 alveolar exudates and interlobular involvement, ultimately prognosticating deterioration [1].

Given the high levels of cytokines induced by SARS-CoV-2, treatment to 77 reduce inflammation-related lung damage is critical. Any intervention to reduce inflammation 78 will, however, affect negatively the viral clearance. Infection of liver cells with SARS-CoV-2 cannot be excluded, as 2-10% 99 of patients with COVID-19 have diarrhoea and viral RNA has been detected in both stool and 100 blood samples, which implies the possibility of hepatic virus presence [5]. It is also likely that 101 any immune-mediated inflammation, in particular cytokine storm, but also pneumonia-102 associated hypoxia, may lead to liver damage in critically ill COVID-19 patients [4]. C-103 reactive protein (CRP) levels are increased in COVID-19 patients and it has been shown that 104 survivors had median CRP values of approximately 40 mg/L, while non-survivors had 105 median values of 125 mg/L, indicating a strong correlation with disease severity and 106 prognosis [6] (Table 1). Other predictors of poor outcome include the serum levels of ferritin 107 and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Elevated ferritin levels due to secondary hemophagocytic 108 lymphohistiocytosis (sHLH) and cytokine storm syndrome have been reported in severe 109 COVID-19 patients. Based on body temperature, organomegaly, blood cell cytopenia, 110 triglycerides, fibrinogen as well as AST and ferritin levels, a predictive H-score was proposed 111 to estimate the risk of developing secondary hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis [7].

FIGREF5.text: -survivors showed significantly higher levels of plasma D-dimers and fibrin 115 degradation products, increased prothrombin times and activated partial thromboplastin 116 times compared to survivors [8]. Coagulopathy and overt disseminated intravascular 117 coagulation appear to be associated with high mortality rates. Among the coagulation 118 parameters, D-dimer elevation >1 ug/L was the strongest independent predictor of mortality 119 [2]. Elevated cardiac troponin I levels indicating heart injury are also predictive of mortality in 120 critically ill patients [9;10]. 121 122 The haematological and coagulation parameters summarized here as well as increased 123 inflammatory reactions caused by various cytokines and liver enzymes are a globally 124 observed phenomenon in COVID-19 patients. While the clinical status, in particular SpO 2 125 levels and concurrent comorbidities of COVID-19 patients largely determines the need of 126 their admittance to ICUs, several laboratory parameters may facilitate the assessment of 127 disease severity and rational triaging. The more several or all of these parameters are 128 altered, the more likely it is that the course of the disease will be unfavourable. In 129 hospitalized patients, clinicians should consider low lymphocyte count as well as the serum 130 levels of CRP, D-dimers, ferritin and IL-6 which may be used in risk stratification to predict 131 severe and fatal COVID-19. In order to further support clinical decision making, large 132 datasets and sound metanalyses are now urgently required.
